did.abstract: The Verazzano-Narrows Bridge collection includes publications, ephemera, and artifacts relating to the building of the bridge and its 1964 opening.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: The majority of the collection was the gift of the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority, 1964. Additional items were the gift of Benjamin Reese Bartel, secretary of Staten Island stamp committee (Staten Island Philatelic Society), 1964, and John La Corte.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection materials are grouped into folders by type.

bioghist.head: Historical note
bioghist.p: The Verrazzano-Narrows Bridge is a suspension bridge that connects the New York City boroughs of Brooklyn and Staten Island. The bridge is named for the Italian explorer Giovanni da Verrazzano, the first known European explorer to enter New York Harbor and the Hudson River, and for the body of water it spans, called the Narrows. Construction on the bridge began in the summer of 1959 and the bridge's upper deck was opened in November of 1964. The lower deck of the bridge was completed in 1969. The construction of the bridge was the last major project overseen by New York State Parks Commissioner and Head of the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority, Robert Moses.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This collection was originally minimally processed to the collection level. In May 2023, the collection was reprocessed to the file level by Dee Bowers. This included rehousing the artifacts (including emptying the Domino sugar packet), photocopying original newsprint and discarding the originals, discarding duplicates, and clarifying the collection's provenance.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Verazzano-Narrows Bridge collection spans the period 1959 to 1965 and measures 0.2 linear feet. The materials in the collection document the bridge's construction and the opening of its upper deck in 1964 and includes programs for the grand opening ceremonies, newspaper clippings, pamphlets, maps, press releases, event invitations, and other memorabilia and ephemera.
